qas.question: What time was the crucifiction per Mark?
What time did Jesus die per Mark?
Why do scholars say the times are different depending on the gospel it's written in?

answers.text: based on the use of Roman timekeeping in John but not in Mark

qas.question: What is another reason the times differ so much?

answers.text: no standardization of timepieces, or exact recording of hours and minutes was available

qas.question: How close was time guessed in the day of the Gospels?

answers.text: approximated to the closest three-hour period

qas.question: What time did Pilate hold court in the morning?
What did Pilate call for to make it easier to tell time?
During what time period was Pilate avaliable to be seen?
What did Pilate want with the Roman empire?
What was rejected by Rome when Pilate brought reconciliation to the table?

context: In Mark 15:25 crucifixion takes place at the third hour <b5_0>(<a0_0>9 a.m.<a0_0/>)<b5_0/> and Jesus' death at the ninth hour (<a1_0>3 p.m.<a1_0/>). However, in John 19:14 Jesus is still before Pilate at the sixth hour. Scholars have presented a number of arguments to deal with the issue, some suggesting <b8_0>a reconciliation<b8_0/>, e.g., <a2_0>based on the use of Roman timekeeping in John but not in Mark<a2_0/>, yet others have rejected <b9_0>the arguments<b9_0/>. Several notable scholars have argued that the modern precision of marking the time of day should not be read back into the gospel accounts, written at a time when <a3_0>no <b6_0>standardization of timepieces<b6_0/>, or exact recording of hours and minutes was available<a3_0/>, and time was often <a4_0>approximated to the closest <b7_0>three-hour period<b7_0/><a4_0/>.
